Posts.Content: Kristin, you have to take charge of your health. If one doc's answer doesn't seem right, then get another opinion. The fact that you have two sisters diagnosed with breast cancer premenapause would give me enough cause and determination to find someone who was going to give a reason for the pain. I have a very strong family history of breast cancer, maternal grandmother, mother, sister and several cousins who have been diagnosed so I read everything. I've had four biopsies in the last 15 years, all benign, thank goodness. Call the American Cancer Society and see if they can recommend a breast specialist in your area. Good luck, Amy
Posts.Title: Severe breast pain with no diagnosis

Posts.Content: Hi Sophie56, As I stated in one of my past posts to you, when my mother was diagnosed with breast cancer, she was stage IV. She lived 18 years from the time she was diagnosed and felt pretty good most of the time. There are a lot of options out there and I think I would definately get a second opinion. What did your doctor suggest as treatment for you? Please keep in touch.
Posts.Title: Death from stage III cancer

Posts.Content: Caroline, Wishing you a good outcome with your procedure. You're in my thoughts and prayers.
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: Hi Girls, I was reading your posts since I was just diagnosed with breast cancer 1 week ago. Will see the surgeon tomorrow and will set up my initial oncology and genetic testing appts. So, right now, I don't know much yet about my situation. But I was pleasantly surprised to hear some of you mention MD Anderson Cancer Centers and your positive opinion of them because I chose the MD Anderson Center affiliated with Cooper Hospital here in NJ. I am hoping that I made the right choice.
Posts.Title: Stage 1 breast cancer 1 2

Posts.Content: Hi Terry, I forgot to mention that before my biopsy yesterday, I talked to my surgeon about my having taken the Tamoxifen and she said that according to my family history without having taken it, she'd estimate my risk at being about 52%. Having taken it, she says she would guess that it would have cut my risk down to about 20%. Unitl I get my results, I honestly don't know if I would have taken it if given the chance to do it over. I will let you know when I get the results. Amy
Posts.Title: If you are on tamoxifen.....

Posts.Content: Hi Terry, Just wanted to let you know that my biopsy was benign. The surgeon said the microcalcifications were associated with several tiny cysts. So until my next mammogram, I can relax. Amy
Posts.Title: If you are on tamoxifen.....

Posts.Content: Wow, I think you must have been one of the few fortunate ones. I spoke to several women before starting tamoxifen as well as my mom's group of oncologists and all said that most women experienced side effects. Amy
Posts.Title: If you are on tamoxifen.....

Posts.Content: Hi Terry, My Mom was on Tamoxifen for several years after she was diagnosed with breast cancer and did very well with it. She was post-menapause when diagnosed, stage 4. When that stopped working, the docs used arimidex and a couple of other drugs. I took Tamoxifen for 5 years due to the high risk of breast cancer in our family. That was 8 years ago and I was 44 years old, pre-menapause. With me I was basically thrown into menapause, hot flashes, mood swings, large weight gain. I don't even know if it was worth it. I am waiting for results of a stereotactic breast biopsy that I had done today to have microcalcifications biopsied that were found on my annual mammogram last month. I hope this helps. Good Luck, Amy
Posts.Title: If you are on tamoxifen.....

Posts.Content: Hi Lady1954, Sorry to hear about your issues that are going on. Thought I would just give you a little info about what to expect with the wire localization that you are to have done. I had a lumpectomy (dx'd with invasive carcinoma in August) and they had to do the same thing before the procedure. They will position you like you were having a mammogram. Based on those films, they use a hollow needle to localize the area all while being compressed. You will be given local anesthetic and shouldn't feel anything...if you do, tell them & they will give you more anesthetic. After they find the area, they slip a needle through the hole & it has an anchor that will attach to the tissue to keep it in place. It's not fun but not unbearable. Will keep you in my thoughts and prayers.
Posts.Title: Bleeding nipple on Right Breast with Suspicious Tumor

Posts.Content: Hi, I had a Mammotone Stereotactic Biopsy about a month ago and I really thought it wasn't bad at all. You lay on a table with your breast hanging through a hole but the table is padded. They compress your breast while they mark where the calcifications are. But the compression wasn't as tight as it is during a regular mammogram. With me, they first numbed the breast with lidocaine and all I felt was a pinch. The surgeon made a small cut just big enough to insert the probe that would collect the tissue. From then on, I felt nothing. They shot a "marker" that permenantly stays in the breast, so if the results were malignant, the surgeon would be able to find the area and radiologists will watch this area when future mammograms are done. They took some films before they removed the tissue. It sounded like a vacuum cleaner was running while she removed 8 tissue samples. After she took the samples, they xrayed the tissue to make sure the calcifications were retrieved. I had minimal bruising with very little pain or discomfort. I know that you're very scared but remember most biopsies (80%) are benign. Mine was. Let me know how things go. I hope this helped.
Posts.Title: scared, please help

Posts.Content: Hi, I had a sterotactic biopsy in 2008 for microcalcifications. Calcifications are quite common in women but what determines if they need to be biopsied are their size, their appearance, are their borders regular or irregular, are they scattered or clustered, etc. In my case they were clustered tightly and my mammo's BIRAD rating was 4, meaning that it was highly suspicious. I had the procedure and it was benign, the calcifications were caused by tiny cysts that were not picked up on the mammogram. 80% of microcalcifications when biopsied are benign. I know how nervous and confused you must be, you're right, the waiting is terrible but please try not to panick. I have a very high instance of breast cancer in my family and have had several open and needle biopsies prior to the stereotactic one and so far all has come back good. Let us know how you make out.
Posts.Title: Stereotactic biopsy - Confused 1 2

Posts.Content: Hi CarolineNC, I was very surprised at how comfortable I was when I had my stereotactic biopsy in 2008. They had me put a gown on and lay face down on a special table with the breast that needed the biopsy through a hole in the table. The dr. injected an anesthestic and I felt a little pinch from the needle. From then on, I felt nothing. She explained everything that she was doing. They use mammography to locate the cluster and shoot (not a good descriptive word) a marker into the breast. That marker is there permanently in the breast. There is a lot of noise from the machines. It almost sounds like a running vacuum cleaner but I felt no pain. I drove myself to and from the procedure. Had no discomfort after the anesthetic wore off. You will have a tiny scar, maybe a 1/2 inch where they went in. I hope this helps calm your fears. Good luck and keep us posted.
Posts.Title: Stereotactic biopsy - Confused 1 2

Posts.Content: Quote: Originally Posted by ladyabby Hi CarolineNC, I was very surprised at how comfortable I was when I had my stereotactic biopsy in 2008. They had me put a gown on and lay face down on a special table with the breast that needed the biopsy through a hole in the table. The dr. injected an anesthestic and I felt a little pinch from the needle. From then on, I felt nothing. She explained everything that she was doing. They use mammography to locate the cluster and shoot (not a good descriptive word) a marker into the breast. That marker is there permanently in the breast. There is a lot of noise from the machines. It almost sounds like a running vacuum cleaner but I felt no pain. The whole procedure took about a half hour. I drove myself to and from the procedure. Had no discomfort after the anesthetic wore off. You will have a tiny scar, maybe a 1/2 inch where they went in. I hope this helps calm your fears. Good luck and keep us posted.
Posts.Title: Stereotactic biopsy - Confused 1 2

Posts.Content: Hi CarolineNC, You are in my thoughts and prayers today.
Posts.Title: Stereotactic biopsy - Confused 1 2

Posts.Content: Hi CarolineNC, Horray that your results came back as no cancer!!! As for the Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia, I have 2 friends who have that and they are monitored by a breast surgeon and have mammograms done every 6 months. Both have had this for years and so far they have been fine. Are you seeing a breast surgeon or a general surgeon? I always felt more comfortable with a breast surgeon because that's all they did. As far a having another biopsy done, I think I would speak your doctor about it and see what he says. Good luck and do keep us posted.
Posts.Title: Stereotactic biopsy - Confused 1 2

Posts.Content: Hi Tinamarie, I too, am at high risk for breast cancer and after consulting my gyn went on Tamoxifen for 5 years. We both felt that the benefits of taking the medication far outweighed the risks. I've been off it now for 3 years. I did have the "hot flashes, weight gain", etc. sometimes associated with taking it. But it wasn't so bad. At least, I feel that I've done everything short of surgery to prevent breast cancer. Hope this helps. Amy
Posts.Title: To take Tamoxifen...that's the question!

Posts.Content: Hi Sarasota2004, Thank you for your recent post. I am so glad that my experiences are helpful to someone else. Life is hard and sometimes very unfair but it helps keeping informed about health issues. I will be thinking about and praying for you next Wednesday.
Posts.Title: Stereotactic biopsy - Confused 1 2

Posts.Content: Hi Sarasota2004, I know how scared and anxious you are. I've been there. Just keep in mind that the odds are in your favor that this will be benign. We have no control over the hand that we're dealt in life but I've found that having faith in God has gotten me through some really tough times. You mentioned about the docs putting a metal clip in at the spot they are biopsying. I too, have one of those markers and it gives me great confort in knowing that everytime I have a mammogram, that area of concern is being watched closer with the clip acting as a flag that there was a past problem. Good luck tomorrow. I will be praying for you.
Posts.Title: Stereotactic biopsy - Confused 1 2

Posts.Content: Hi Sarasota2004, Am so sorry that they weren't able to do the sterotactic biopsy and that you now have to have an open one. I've never had wires with any of my previous open biopsies so I can't give you any input on what to expect. Since you are so anxious you may want to have your primary give you something to help calm you. I know this is very nerve wracking, the waiting is terrible. Am praying for you.
Posts.Title: Stereotactic biopsy - Confused 1 2

Posts.Content: Hi Just an FYI. From working in the medical field for 30 plus years and from my own personal experiences, you have every right to request another radiologist's opinion within the group or take your films to another facility for a second opinion if you're not comfortable with the results and recommendations that you're being given. The one thing that I've learned over the years and have stressed to others, we need to take charge of our health and not leave everything in the hands of others. If you're not sure of something, ask questions and if you don't get answers thant make sense to you, get another opinion. I hope this helps.
Posts.Title: Stereotactic biopsy - Confused 1 2

Posts.Content: Hi, My stereotactic biopsy also took about 30 minutes. I have a very strong history of breast cancer in my family, my maternal grandmother, my mother, my sister and several maternal cousins all diagnosed with it so I was relieved but somewhat surprised when it came back benign. I had the biopsy on a Monday and had the results on Thursday. Try to keep yourself busy. If you have a hobby that you enjoy then throw yourself into it. Whatever you can do that you enjoy to keep your mind off of things. It really does help ease the waiting. I have a 22 month old grandson who is truly the joy of my life, so I spent many hours with him. Take care.
Posts.Title: scared, please help

Posts.Content: Hi, Microcalcifications are quite common. What determines if they are classified as suspicious are their size, are they regular or irregular shaped, are they clustered in a group, etc. They sometimes do indicate the pressence of cancer but 80% of those biopsied turn out to be benign. I had to have a stereotactic biopsy in 2008 when my mammo showed tightly clustered microcalcifications. The radiologist gave it a BIRAD's rating of 4 which is highly suspicious. I have a very strong family history of breast cancer so I was conerned. The results came back benign, the calcifications were due to tiny microscopic cysts that did not show up on the mammogram. My advice as to whether to wait the 6 months for a repeat mammo or to ask for a biopsy would be to go with your gut feeling. If you're ok with waiting then do so, but if you're uneasy about going that route, ask for the biopsy. If it were me, I'd have the biopsy even if I didn't have the breast cancer historyl
Posts.Title: Microcalcifications, age 39, confused

Posts.Content: Hi, Indeterminate means that they can't be sure by the appearance of the calcifications if they represent a malignancy or not. Calcifications are pretty common but some have to be checked into. The size, shape, regular or irregular borders, how they are grouped (ex:tightly clustered microcalcifications are much more worrisome that microcalcifications that are scattered throughout the breast). 80% of microcalcifications turn out to be benign so the odds are in your favor. I have a strong family history of breast cancer and have had several biopsies over the years. I had a stereotactic biopsy in 2008 for microcalcifications and they turned out fine. If it were me, I would opt for the biopsy for peace of mind.
Posts.Title: Confused about calcifications

Posts.Content: Hi, I had a Mammotone Stereotactic Biopsy almost a month ago and I really thought it wasn't bad at all. Yes, you do lay on a table with your breast hanging through a hole but the table is padded. They compress your breast while they mark where the calcifications are. But the compression wasn't as tight as it is during a regular mammogram. With me, they first numbed the breast with lidocaine and all I felt was a pinch. The surgeon made a small cut just big enough to insert the probe that would collect the tissue. From then on, I felt nothing. They shot a "marker" that permenantly stays in the breast, so if the results were malignant, the surgeon would be able to find the area and radiologists will watch this area when future mammograms are done. They took some films before they removed the tissue. It sounded like a vacuum cleaner was running while she removed 8 tissue samples. After she took the samples, they xrayed the tissue to make sure the calcifications were retrieved. I had minimal bruising with very little pain or discomfort. The surgeon told me that 80% of calcifications biopsied are benign. Mine were benign. Good luck and I hope this helps.
Posts.Title: What are Linear Calcifications in your Breast?

Posts.Content: Hi, Take the script that the doctor gave you and go to a different radiology facility. No one has the right to refuse to do what your doctor is ordering. I think I would then report them to the Better Business Bureau or the governing board of radiology in your state. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Lesion on Left Breast

Posts.Content: Hi Tori, I too, had a biopsy for microcalcifications in April and the report was benign. It's true that 80% of breast biopsies are benign. Read my posts under ladyabby. I hope this helps.
Posts.Title: Had a mammogram monday and showed microcalcifications

Posts.Content: Hi Tara, From what I've been told and read, any description stating round, oval, smooth leans towards benign findings. I was recently diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma, stage one. Very close to that mass was a complex firbroadenoma. Pathology on that showed lobular carcinoma insitu which is not a true cancer but a high risk marker...meaning that it could at some point change. Keeping on top of your breast health is very stressful but it is doable. As far as the dr. wanting to do a biopsy on the enlarged axillary node, I think it's a good thing that she did. Show's that she/he is very thorough when dealing with the unknown. It gives me great peace to know that so much is available with testing, diagnostic and treatment options. Remember that 80% of "suspicious" findings turn out to be benign. Let us know when you get the results.
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer or Benign Scare?????

Posts.Content: I was just diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma and lobular carcinoma insitu on 8/9/14 and I can't stress enough that if something doesn't feel right and your dr. won't work with you on it, then get another opinion. A little hx about me...am 58 yo with strong family history of breast ca...maternal grandmother, mother both diagnosed in their mid 50s. So I have always been consistent with doing my yearly mammos, monthly self exams, having 2 clinical breast exams yearly and I even took a 5 year course of Tamoxifen when I was in my early 40s. Over the past 20 years, I have had 5 biopsies, which all came back benign except this last one. A few weeks ago, I started noticing that my right breast would ache/throb...it wasn't terrible but it felt different. Before menopause, I always had painful, lumpy, fibrocystic breasts and was always told when I had my mammograms that I had very dense breast tissue but since going through menopause, I haven't had any breast discomfort in years. So I made an appt with my gyn and he did an exam and said that he really didn't didn't feel anything of concern but due to my history ordered an diagnostic mammo and US. Had the tests done and the radiologist said that there was no change on the mammo but that he "didn't know what he was looking at" on the US and recommended a US needle guided biopsy. I made an appt with a breast surgeon who sent my films down to their breast imaging. The radiologist called me herself the next day and said "yes, she agreed that their was no change on the mammo but that she was very concerned about the US". She saw 2 masses, one that she was extremely concerned about and scheduled the biopsy the next day. She explained that her facility was using a new technology, designed as a diagnostic tool for patients with dense breast tissue. It is called Contrast Enhanced Spectrum Mammogram (CESM) and was developed by GE. I was given an iodine contrast via IV (similar to how a CT is done) It uses the standard mammogram equipment and takes 2 images of each side, 1 image identical to the mammogram. Dense breast tissue shows up as very bright, busy imaging that they refer to as "noise". The 2nd image utilizes the CESM technology and hides all the "noise" so that the only thing that are highlighted are abnormal areas. So, the 2 masses that she saw lit up like a light bulb. I went from the mammo room to US where she did 2 biopsies. She called me 3 days later with the cancer diagnosis and am now in the process of endless dr. appts and testing. My advice to you would be to have your breast imaging done at a breast imaging facility because that's all they do all day, every day. Ask questions and if something doesn't sound right, get another opinion. When I got my imaging and pathology reports, I sent my reports to John Hopkins. It is a lot of information thrown at you and there are a lot of decisions that need to be made, so it gave me peace of mind to know that what was being done in my case was considered standard/correct care. Good luck and keep it touch.
Posts.Title: im new here and scared

Posts.Content: Hi, I was on Tamoxifen for 5 years for preventative reasons due to an extremely high breast cancer history in my family. I experienced the fatigue, the hot flashes, the mood swings and gained a lot of weight. These are all common side effects of the drug and I knew that before I started taking it but I felt that the benefits were worth it. Now, 6 years after having stopped taking it, I'm working very hard trying to get the weight that I gained while on the drug off. But again, I think the benefits are worth it. Good luck, Amy
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen?
